discoveredAssets: localhost:5001 - Dalgona Challenges web application - Flask/Werkzeug 1.0.1 on Python 2.7.12 - Port 5001 - Security challenge platform
localhost:5001/ - Main landing page - No authentication - References broken/inactive link to xss25 challenge
localhost:5001/static/ - Static file serving - CSS, images, and assets - No directory listing - Port 5001
localhost:5001/static/css/style.css - Main stylesheet - 2110 bytes - Caching enabled

targets.objective: Test the main Flask application for: legacy Python 2.7 vulnerabilities, Flask/Werkzeug 1.0.1 known CVEs, Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI), security header misconfigurations, HTTP method abuse, query parameter injection, and application logic flaws related to the broken xss25 challenge link
targets.rationale: Application runs on EOL Python 2.7.12 (unsupported since 2020) with Werkzeug 1.0.1 development server. Missing all security headers (X-Frame-Options, CSP, X-XSS-Protection, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options). Server header exposes version information. The xss25 challenge link appears broken/inactive which may indicate routing issues or hidden functionality. Development server not suitable for production use.

targets.objective: Test static file handler for: path traversal vulnerabilities, source code disclosure via static path manipulation, directory listing bypass, arbitrary file read, and access to unintended files through static file serving misconfiguration
targets.rationale: Static file serving through Flask may have path traversal vulnerabilities. Font files are referenced in CSS but fonts directory returns 404, suggesting potential access control issues. Static handler using old Werkzeug version may have known vulnerabilities.

targets.objective: Test query parameter handling for: reflected XSS (parameters appear to be ignored but may be processed server-side), SQL/NoSQL injection if database backend exists, command injection, SSTI via query parameters, and parameter pollution attacks
targets.rationale: Application ignores query parameters in responses but may process them server-side. The platform is designed for XSS challenges (xss25 reference) indicating XSS testing is relevant. Legacy Python version increases risk of injection vulnerabilities.

targets.objective: Investigate the broken/inactive xss25 challenge link through: brute-force of similar endpoints (xss1-xss30, variations with hyphens/underscores/slashes), testing alternative routing patterns, session/cookie-based routing, HTTP header manipulation, and POST/PUT methods to activate the challenge
targets.rationale: Main page explicitly links to 'xss25' challenge which returns 404. This may indicate: disabled functionality, session-based routing, authentication requirement, or routing misconfiguration. As a security challenge platform, finding the correct way to access challenges is critical for comprehensive testing.

targets.objective: Test for hidden administrative interfaces through: endpoint enumeration (admin, administrator, console, debug, config, manage), HTTP method variations (POST, PUT, OPTIONS), authentication bypass techniques, default credentials, and HTTP header-based access control bypass
targets.rationale: As a challenge platform, there may be administrative interfaces for challenge management, user scoring, or configuration. These are high-value targets often protected by weak authentication. No admin endpoints discovered but thorough testing needed given the minimal attack surface.

targets.objective: Discover and test potential API endpoints for: REST API functionality (/api/challenges, /api/xss25, /api/users), authentication/authorization flaws, IDOR in API resources, mass assignment vulnerabilities, API versioning issues, and GraphQL endpoints if present
targets.rationale: Modern web applications typically have API backends for AJAX functionality. The minimal front-end suggests functionality may be API-driven. No API endpoints discovered yet but comprehensive enumeration needed. Challenge platforms often use APIs for score tracking and challenge management.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] Legacy Python 2.7.12 (End-of-Life since January 2020) - No security updates available, numerous known vulnerabilities
[CRITICAL] Werkzeug 1.0.1 development server in use - Not suitable for production, potential for known CVEs and exploitation
[HIGH] Missing all security headers: X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, X-Content-Type-Options, Strict-Transport-Security
[HIGH] Server header exposes version information (Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.12) - Information disclosure aids attackers
[MEDIUM] Broken challenge link to /xss25 - May indicate routing misconfiguration, disabled functionality, or hidden access method
[MEDIUM] Extremely minimal attack surface - Only root endpoint and static files accessible - May indicate hidden functionality or incomplete deployment
[MEDIUM] Application accepts only GET, HEAD, OPTIONS methods on root - POST returns 405 but other endpoints not tested
[LOW] Static files served with proper caching headers - No directory listing enabled
[LOW] No robots.txt or sitemap.xml present - Limited documentation of application structure
[INFO] Application titled 'Dalgona Challenges' - Security challenge/CTF training platform focused on XSS vulnerabilities
